body:
I agree.

That's why in my suggestion, if a user searches for a category, then guilds that are directly under that category *and* guilds that have tagged to that category in their description pull up. If a user has blocked a tag, then all guilds with that tag in their description are hidden from them.

That issue is also a catalyst for the alliances idea.

Example:

I search for the Programming category > Every guild that is categorized under programming comes up AND every guild with a #programming tag in the description is pulled up even if they're actually directly categorized under something else, because the #programming tag indicated an overlap and that it's relevant to the category.

I use another example of similar guilds with +Bread and +breads to demonstrate how Alliances can help with duplicate guilds in my original post.

author.bio_html:

body:
The goal for the FP is for it randomly pick 1-2 posts from each category's hot list. So you've got hot items from each category, and it picks 1 or 2 from each. Enough to get 25 listings going. Now, cap still has to look into this as the last attempt (a few months ago) proved to be inefficient for the backend to compute.

Non-logged users would be greeted with a diversified FP until they either pick categories in the sidebar or sign up to customize. User onboarding will be a thing which will prompt new users to select categories (alphabetical order) and then pick guilds that fall under these cats (probably using same trending algo we use on /browse).

As for categories, I was hoping we would have ToS clarified before something like what has happened took place. We are going to update ToS with a section on categories, specifically regarding how they can be used and what is considered abuse of the feature. Basically, don't put something like +animals under the arts category.

As for enforcement; that's still being decided. Now, obviously, admins have the ability to go in and change a cat but I don't think this is a good practice without at least attempting to get in touch with a GM. Another admin option, for guilds that abuse categories, would be to simply remove their category (instead of reassigning it) and notify the GM.

I think that last option has a downside in terms of guild visibility. Is it bad for an admin to move +animals from arts category to a more relevant category? Another option could be making an "uncategorized" catch-all category to dump guilds in if they abuse categories or were never assigned one by their GM.

Now, offensive sub-cat was recently added while I was offline. Unfortunately, I believe this cat prematurely without too much thought into it. What some deem "offensive" is just subjective after all.

I haven't attempted to create a guild but it should require categorization by design. So we eventually all guilds on ruqqus in a category. Selecting multiple categories or even #tags for better discovery is still to be discussed and developed.

I haven't attempted to create a guild but it should require categorization by design. So we eventually all guilds on ruqqus in a category. Selecting multiple categories or even #tags for better discovery is still to be discussed and developed.
